Todd,The fields and data look good in your table."is the role created in the same manner as course_id and user_id?" The 'role' field is a bit misleading as we are not required to build a Role table and use the role field as a foreign key (which would be best practice) - as myself and Harcharan discussed in another thread instead we only have to insert the values (0,1) into the role field. Any query retrieving information from the role field will return a 1 or 0 (not a text description like Student or Lecturer) . The code provided for Member table, see below, is enough to set up the field and we are only asked to populate it with the 0's and 1's provided. If you included 'role' in the primary key line it may be causing the problem by affecting the sort?Harcharan,"Member table fields come as : User.id, Course.title, role [there's no primary key here]"I understood that the primary key should be the pair of foreign keys 'User.id and Course.title' as per the lines from the original roster.py file provided?CREATE TABLE Member ( user_id INTEGER, course_id INTEGER, role INTEGER, PRIMARY KEY (user_id, course_id) from the SQLite docs you can only make one primary key declaration (hence the last line) i.e. adding PRIMARY KEY to the user_id and course_id lines separately would cause an error (have not tested this)

It is not a primary key... The Member table resolves the many to many relationship issue and role is an attribute of this table. Simple attribute...</text><text>User table : id, name [id is the primary key]</text><text>Course table : id, title [id is the primary key]</text><text>Since Many users can take up Many courses,</text><text>Member table fields come as : User.id, Course.title, role [there's no primary key here]</text><text>Just make an Entity-Relation diagram and map like Dr. Chuck did. Hope this helps.</text></co-content>

Harcharan I had responded to your other post before seeing this one"looks like when we INSERT or IGNORE --- that's where the auto_number should not get incremented" I looked through the SQLite docs (posted excerpt in another thread) the IGNORE is what causes gaps in the id sequence and is 'correct behaviour' (at least for SQLite) for incrementing a table's unique id field - gaps in id sequence are not a problem as the ids are all still unique.The code posted above creates a role table (I did too) but strictly speaking it is not required as you are only asked to populate the member table. "store the role column in the Member table to complete the assignment"note that in the member table provided the role field is called just that 'role' not 'role_id' so, by naming convention at least, is not being used as an foreign key.

I thought through and did more investigation... looks like when we INSERT or IGNORE --- that's where the auto_number should not get incremented. IGNORE causes SQLite not to throw errors on duplicate entries given the UNIQUE constraint on the field, but I think I am also looking for "NOT INCREMENTING" the sequence on ID.Anyone else noticed this issue? And knows a solution?

"use of saving current sequence and then resetting if insert or ignore actually didn't add anything"This can be achieved by read/write to the sqlite_sequence table (automatically created once there are fields with auto increment) ...see this thread...https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5586269/how-can-i-reset-a-autoincrement-sequence-number-in-sqliteBut I have to ask why you want to do this? It bothered me when I first saw the gaps (even in Dr Chucks video and he skipped over it) but having read up I was happy to accept and proceed in the knowledge that it is 'normal behaviour'from the official docs..."The content of the sqlite_sequence table can be modified using ordinary UPDATE, INSERT, and DELETE statements. But making modifications to this table will likely perturb the AUTOINCREMENT key generation algorithm. Make sure you know what you are doing before you undertake such changes."I have to add that in reviewing code elsewhere many people do seem to populate the id sequence explicitly when importing data but it only makes sense to me when populating a foreign key field.

The wrapped SQL command/script is then passed to (and interpreted by) the SQL engine.</text><text>Works fine with single quotes too as long as the line does not wrap to a second line and there are no inner single quotes to confuse things. So looks like the usual string quote rules apply.</text><text/></co-content>

<co-content><text>I would like to add that in order to get that exact output given in the sample on the assignment page you need to make a slight modification to the given code in your ORDER BY clause.  You need to also order by track title.  You need to be explicit about that since a relational database model is inherently an unordered model.</text></co-content>

<co-content><text>The names of the columns right after the SELECT keyword determines the order of the columns in the output. The ORDER BY clause determines the order of the rows. </text><text>In this case the ordering only affects the Artist name column. Since AC/DC comes first, and there are more than 3 tracks by AC/DC, you only see one artist in the output. The rest of the ordering is arbitrary. Just like a Python dict, the sequence of a database table is not preserved.</text></co-content>

The main source for receiving this kind of error is not successfully removing the whitespace including the newline character when extracting the domain name. That can be accomplished in more than one way. Please be aware that the split() method, when used without the sep argument automatically removes whitespace. Here's an example:>>> s = " abc def gh ijk 123 " >>> s.split() ['abc', 'def', 'gh', 'ijk', '123']When split() is used with a sep argument a different splitting algorithm occurs. As far as the order is concerned, the relational database model is inherently an unordered model so unless you use an ORDER BY clause the results will not be ordered. The assignment is not requiring you to have the data ordered but you can create an additional table for checking purposes producing the top ten or 15 results if you wish or you can order the whole table but that is not required.

<co-content><text>To understand this issue you need to be aware of the concept of type affinity in Sqlite. The recommended (or preferred)  type for data stored in a column is called type affinity.   The type affinities in Sqlite are INTEGER, TEXT, BLOB, REAL, NUMERIC.  There are certain rules that determine type affinity.  One of these rules states that If the declared type of the column contains any of the strings "CHAR", "CLOB", or "TEXT" then that column is assigned TEXT affinity.  So, therefore, type VARCHAR has TEXT affinity.</text><text>But to get back to what you are trying to do, it looks like you are trying to use the wizard in Sqlite to create your table and field names.  Instead of that you can click the Execute SQL tab and enter the commands given to you in the lecture.</text></co-content>
<co-content><text>SQLite doesn't have a VARCHAR type, the closest match is TEXT.</text></co-content>
